relevance.please_evaluate_quality: Please, evaluate quality of the result! Words in the results should be semantically related to the query -- synonyms, hyponyms, associations, and so on.
relevance.relevant: relevant -- most of the results are relevant for you
relevance.mix: mix -- some results are relevant some are not
relevance.non_relevant: non-relevant -- most of the results are not relevant
relevance.description: Please remember that you provide your own opinion on the quality of the results. If the words in the results sound related to you -- use 1. If not at all -- use 3. The words in the results should be semantically related to the query in a broad sense. They can be synonyms, hyponyms, co-hyponyms, strong associations...

about.title: About
about.description: This system is a kind of "lexico-semantic search engine". Given a text query it provides a list of related words. A traditional search engine provides as a results a list of related documents. The current version is based on two semantic similarity measures -- Serelex and PatternSim. The first relies on definitions of words, while the second relies on a text corpus. This is an ongoing project, please write your suggestions or comments to Alexander Panchenko (alexander.panchenko@uclouvain.be)
about.api_description: You can access the system without any limitations as following: http://serelex.cental.be/find/norm60-corpus-all/ubuntu. This request should return a set of words related to 'ubuntu' in JSON format:

search.for_example:
System finds semantically related words.
For example

models.norm60-corpus-all:
This semantic similarity measure relies on frequency of relation extraction with lexico-syntactic patterns (Efreq), number of relations between words (Rnum), frequency of the words in a corpus (Cfreq) and number of distinct patterns extracted a given relation (Pnum).
For details please refer to the following paper: Panchenko A., Morozova O., Naets H. A Semantic Similarity Measure Based on Lexico-Syntactic Patterns. // In Proceedings of 11th Conference on Natural Language Processing (KONVENS 2012), — Vienna (Austria), pp.174--178, 2012.
models.pairs-all-raw-sort:
This semantic similarity measure relies on frequency of relation extraction with lexico-syntactic patterns (Efreq) from WaCky and ukWaC corpora.
For details please refer to the following paper: Panchenko A., Morozova O., Naets H. A Semantic Similarity Measure Based on Lexico-Syntactic Patterns. // In Proceedings of 11th Conference on Natural Language Processing (KONVENS 2012), — Vienna (Austria), pp.174--178, 2012.
models.norm31:
This semantic similarity measure relies on frequency of relation extraction with lexico-syntactic patterns (Enum) and number of relations between words (Rfreq).
For details please refer to the following paper: Panchenko A., Morozova O., Naets H. A Semantic Similarity Measure Based on Lexico-Syntactic Patterns. // In Proceedings of 11th Conference on Natural Language Processing (KONVENS 2012), — Vienna (Austria), pp.174--178, 2012.
models.norm51-corpus:
This semantic similarity measure relies on frequency of relation extraction with lexico-syntactic patterns (Efreq), number of relations between words (Rnum) and frequency of the words in a corpus (Cfreq).
For details please refer to the following paper: Panchenko A., Morozova O., Naets H. A Semantic Similarity Measure Based on Lexico-Syntactic Patterns. // In Proceedings of 11th Conference on Natural Language Processing (KONVENS 2012), — Vienna (Austria), pp.174--178, 2012.
models.norm42:
This semantic similarity measure relies on frequency of relation extraction with lexico-syntactic patterns (Efreq) and frequency of the words in a corpus (Cfreq).
For details please refer to the following paper: Panchenko A., Morozova O., Naets H. A Semantic Similarity Measure Based on Lexico-Syntactic Patterns. // In Proceedings of 11th Conference on Natural Language Processing (KONVENS 2012), — Vienna (Austria), pp.174--178, 2012.
models.raw-pukwac:
This semantic similarity measure relies on frequency of relation extraction with lexico-syntactic patterns (Efreq) from ukWaC corpus.
For details please refer to the following paper: Panchenko A., Morozova O., Naets H. A Semantic Similarity Measure Based on Lexico-Syntactic Patterns. // In Proceedings of 11th Conference on Natural Language Processing (KONVENS 2012), — Vienna (Austria), pp.174--178, 2012.
models.raw-wacky:
This semantic similarity measure relies on frequency of relation extraction with lexico-syntactic patterns (Efreq) from WaCky corpus.
For details please refer to the following paper: Panchenko A., Morozova O., Naets H. A Semantic Similarity Measure Based on Lexico-Syntactic Patterns. // In Proceedings of 11th Conference on Natural Language Processing (KONVENS 2012), — Vienna (Austria), pp.174--178, 2012.
models.cos-mknn-5-12130:
This semantic similarity measure relies on definitions of Wiktionary and Wikipedia, cosine similarity function and MKNN algorithm.
For details please refer to the following paper: Panchenko A., Adeykin S., Romanov A. and Romanov P. Extraction of Semantic Relations between Concepts with KNN Algorithms on Wikipedia. In.: Dmitry I. Ignatov, Sergei O. Kuznetsov, Jonas Poelmans (Eds.) Proceedings of 2nd International Workshop on Concept Discovery in Unstructured Data 2012. Published by KU-Leuven, ISBN 978-9-08-140991-9
